title: More Retirement Myths Debunked: Why ‘the 4% Rule’ Is Outdated
text:
Text size

Many pre-retirees anticipate retirement as an opportune time for kicking back and enjoying things they couldn’t do while they were working.

The trouble is that many of them are still operating under old assumptions—which Barron’s explored in the article “3 Retirement Myths Debunked”—that if not corrected can severely crimp the lifestyle they hope to have.

Beyond these, here are two other potentially debilitating assumptions that can break the retirement bank, if you aren’t careful.

Everyone can safely pull 4% from their portfolio each year in retirement

Known as “the 4% rule,” this is a rule of thumb that determines how much a retiree can safely afford to withdraw every year. Sticking strictly to this measure, however, can leave savers with a significant shortfall if, for example, markets sour or inflation stirs, financial advisors warn.

“The 4% rule was developed using historical data available over 20 years ago and is less relevant to data available now or looking forward,” says Kathleen Stewart, wealth strategist at BNY Mellon Wealth Management. “Over the last several years, lower interest rates and low fixed-income yields have been a factor in retirement planning. Going forward, they may not produce suitable returns necessary to assure that 4% rule works over the long term,” she says.

The danger of holding tight to the idea of a 4% withdrawal rate is that people could outlive their assets or take too much risk to generate the income needed. For example, they could feel the need to hold more stocks than they otherwise would in order to generate the returns necessary to meet their withdrawal needs, she says. This could add a level of risk to their portfolio that may not be prudent given their time horizon.

Most retirees require a greater degree of certainty than sticking to the 4% rule offers, according to Daniel R. Hill, president and CEO of Richmond, Va.-based registered investment advisory Hill Wealth Strategies.

When he works with prospective clients in their early to-mid-60s, he uses a so-called Monte Carlo simulation technique to help them understand their chance of having enough money in retirement. He starts with a 4% withdrawal rate because it’s what people are familiar with—but he doesn’t end up there. That’s because the simulation usually shows a chance they’ll run out of money at that rate.

“If I told you, getting on an airplane, that it had a 90% chance of landing safely, would you get on that plane? It doesn’t seem like a good plan to me if it’s not 100%. We need to have a better plan,” he says.

His advice is for investors to do the math and see what works in their particular situation. For some people, an ideal withdrawal rate may be 5%, 3% or even 2% depending on factors such as the size of their portfolio, how much debt they have, their living expenses, and how they want to spend their retirement.

Stewart of BNY Mellon says it’s also important for retirees to manage and evaluate their withdrawal rates regularly, as markets fluctuate and other life circumstances change, to help ensure retirees stay on track with their plan.

She recommends that investors develop an integrated asset-allocation strategy that works with their expenses. For instance, she says, some retirees may require a more conservative 60% fixed-income allocation (with only 40% in stocks) when their portfolio primarily covers fixed expenses, such as housing, utilities, food, clothing, and transportation.

On the other hand, a slightly more aggressive portfolio could be appropriate for some retirees whose life circumstances are different, she says.

Your tax rate will be lower in retirement

Another commonly false assumption pre-retirees make is that their tax rate will be significantly lower in retirement. They assume because they are no longer bringing in the same level of income, they won’t be paying the same level of taxes.

But often they forget they will still owe taxes on their traditional 401(k) distributions, says Gary Droz, managing director at MainLine Private Wealth, a registered investment advisor in Wynnewood, Pa. He says families—particularly those with household earnings over $100,000—often have a similar tax rate in retirement, or even higher once required minimum distributions are taken into account.

This miscalculation is especially impactful because so many families have such a significant portion of their wealth tied up in a traditional 401(k) and IRS rules don’t allow people to keep the money in these accounts indefinitely. People generally have to start taking distributions from their traditional 401(k) at age 70½ at ordinary income rates. Oftentimes, these amounts are enough to put them over the tax rate they were when they were earning income from their jobs, Droz says.

Had they realized this before retirement, they might have been able to take advantage of the Roth 401(k), which is funded with after-tax dollars and whose withdrawals are tax-free if the account owner is at least 59½ and has held the account for at least five years. Converting a traditional 401(k) to a Roth 401(k) may not make sense because of tax considerations, but a majority of companies that offer a traditional 401(k) plan also offer a Roth 401(k) option, Droz says.

People can ask their employer about the possibility of including this feature if the option doesn’t already exist, he says. “What many individuals fail to realize is that the majority of your retirement account balance at the end of your working life is earnings, not contributions,” Droz says. “If you used a Roth 401(k)? Every dollar of that balance is yours to keep.”

The upshot, Droz says, is this: The concern that people will outlive their money—or be forced to crimp their lifestyle in retirement—is exacerbated by the fact that many retirees underestimate their tax liability. “They don’t consider taxes a viable drag on their cost of living,” he says, “but that’s just not the case.”

description: Retirement savers who hold fast to assumptions like “the 4% rule” on withdrawal rates or that their taxes will fall after their career is over could be in for a surprise.
